keyTakeAways: Federal judge Patricia Tolliver Giles ruled that the removal of race and gender-related books from military base schools was not pedagogically justified but driven by improper partisan motives.
Students at DoDEA schools, children of active-duty service members, claimed their First Amendment rights were violated when books on race, gender, and LGBTQ+ issues were removed.

The Department of Defense Education Activity (DoDEA) implemented policies under executive orders from President Trump and Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth that restricted teaching on Critical Race Theory, gender ideology, and cultural celebrations such as Black History Month.
The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) of Kentucky, Virginia, and national ACLU filed a legal motion to restore removed books and curricula, citing violations of constitutional rights.

Schools canceled events like Black History Month and Holocaust Remembrance Day, and teachers were directed to remove educational materials and posters of figures like Malala Yousafzai and Frida Kahlo.
Judge Giles emphasized that the removals were politically motivated and not based on educational standards or pedagogical needs.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A federal judge has ordered the return of books on race, gender, and LGBTQ+ issues to school libraries at military bases, after students and families alleged that the Department of Defense Education Activity (DoDEA) violated their First Amendment rights by removing such materials in response to executive orders from President Trump and Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth. These orders banned instruction on Critical Race Theory, gender ideology, and DEI, and prohibited celebrations such as Black History Month, Women's History Month, and Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month. Schools canceled events, removed posters of figures like Malala Yousafzai and Frida Kahlo, and teachers were instructed to eliminate discussions on sensitive topics. The ACLU filed a motion on behalf of students, arguing the removals were politically motivated and not based on educational needs. Judge Patricia Tolliver Giles ruled that the actions were improperly partisan, and ordered the immediate restoration of all removed books and curricular materials.
title: Books about race and gender to be returned to school libraries on some military bases
